case_vignette: A 62-year-old man is referred to a gastroenterologist because of difficulty swallowing for the past 5 months. He has difficulty swallowing both solid and liquid foods, but there is no associated pain. He denies any shortness of breath or swelling in his legs. He immigrated from South America 10 years ago. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. His physical examination is unremarkable. A barium swallow study was ordered and the result is given below. Esophageal manometry confirms the diagnosis.
question: What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
